1 | The National Investigation Agency (NIA) attached immovable property and land at Chatra District of Jharkhand belonging to Tritiya Prastuti Committee (TPC), a splinter group of the Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) ‘commander’ identified **Read more...** The National Investigation Agency (NIA) attached immovable property and land at Chatra District of Jharkhand belonging to Tritiya Prastuti Committee (TPC), a splinter group of the Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) ‘commander’ identified as Gopal Singh Bhokta, reports OneIndia News on June 2. An inter-college and 245 decimals of land at Chatra District of Jharkhand were attached by NIA. TPC ‘commander’ Gopal Singh is involved in raising illegal money through extortions and illegal collection of levy. **Read less...** | | June - 1 | Security Forces (SFs) arrested an individual identified as Jagdev Yadav alias Jato Yadav, accused in 16-year-old Naxal \[Left Wing Extremism (LWE)\] case from Vishanpur village of Charkapathar Police Station in Jamui District of Bihar on June 1, repor **Read more...** Security Forces (SFs) arrested an individual identified as Jagdev Yadav alias Jato Yadav, accused in 16-year-old Naxal \[Left Wing Extremism (LWE)\] case from Vishanpur village of Charkapathar Police Station in Jamui District of Bihar on June 1, reports Hindustan. Security Forces (SFs) comprising of Bihar Police and Sashastra Seema Bal (SSB) formed a team and arrested him from his house during the raid. Jagdev Yadav is first accused in Naxal case number 38/2005 registered at Sono Police Station, said Station House Officer (SHO) Abdul Haleem **Read less...** | | June - 1 | Two Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) cadres including a woman were killed in an exchange of fire with Security Forces (SFs) in the dense forest near Bhandarpal village in Kondagaon District of Chhattisgarh on June 1, reports Free Press J **Read more...** Two Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) cadres including a woman were killed in an exchange of fire with Security Forces (SFs) in the dense forest near Bhandarpal village in Kondagaon District of Chhattisgarh on June 1, reports Free Press Journal. Based on information about the presence of CPI-Maoist cadres belonging to the North Kanker-Mainpur Division Coordination Committee in the jungles of Rajpur, Bhandarpal and Timnar villages along the Kondagaon-Kanker District border, the team of the Chhattisgarh Police's District Reserve Guard (DRG) carried out an anti- Naxal \[Left Wing Extremism (LWE)\] operation leading to an encounter with CPI-Maoist cadres on June 1. After the encounter was over, the Police team searched the area and found two bodies of CPI-Maoist cadres, including a woman, clad in uniform. Police recovered one Self Loading Rifle (SLR), 303 rifle and three 12 bore rifles along with a huge cache of arms and ammunition and other materials from the site. Police believe that few more CPI-Maoist cadres could have been injured in the action and search in a nearby area is underway to arrest the CPI-Maoist cadres, who had escaped from the spot, said Inspector General of Police (IG), (Bastar range) Sundarraj P **Read less...** | | June - 1 | Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) ‘sub zonal commander’ identified as Nunuchand Mahto alias Tiger alias Gandhi alias Netaji, carrying a reward of INR 5,00,000 over his head, has surrendered before the Police in Giridih District of Jharkhan **Read more...** Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) ‘sub zonal commander’ identified as Nunuchand Mahto alias Tiger alias Gandhi alias Netaji, carrying a reward of INR 5,00,000 over his head, has surrendered before the Police in Giridih District of Jharkhand on June 1, reports UNI. Speaking to the media after his surrender, Nunuchand said that he was relieved after returning to the mainstream and also urged other CPI-Maoist cadres to follow the same. He has joined CPI-Maoist in 2008. **Read less...** | | June - 1 | Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) ‘sub-zonal commander’ identified as Uday Oraon was arrested by Police at Murhu-Karcha Chhapar Toli village under Pesrar Police Station in Lohardaga District of Jharkhand, reports Dainik Jagran on June 2. U **Read more...** Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) ‘sub-zonal commander’ identified as Uday Oraon was arrested by Police at Murhu-Karcha Chhapar Toli village under Pesrar Police Station in Lohardaga District of Jharkhand, reports Dainik Jagran on June 2. Uday Oraon belongs to Dalam (armed squad) of Ravindra Ganju, the regional ‘commander’ of CPI-Maoist, who carries a reward of INR 1.5 million over his head. The arrested CPI-Maoist sub-zonal commander, Uday Oraon is involved in killing of Munshi, road construction worker under Pesrar Police Station, kidnap and killing of a villager in Mungo in Serendag Police Station area, set ablaze of many vehicles and other Naxal \[Left Wing Extremism (LWE)\] incidents. Intelligence officials along with Police teams have interrogated Uday separately and started work on the Naxal incidents. During the interrogation, Uday had provided information related to the CPI-Maoist outfit including planting series bombs in the forests of Lohardaga District. It has given important information to the Police about weapons, pressure bombs, cane bombs, landmines, Naxal squads. Uday Oraon has been wanted in dozens of cases in Lohardaga, Gumla and Latehar Districts of Jharkhand. **Read less...** | | June - 1 | Police have identified Two Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) cadres including a woman, who were killed in an encounter with Security Forces (SFs) in the dense forest near Bhandarpal village in Kondagaon District of Chhattisgarh on June 1 a **Read more...** Police have identified Two Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) cadres including a woman, who were killed in an encounter with Security Forces (SFs) in the dense forest near Bhandarpal village in Kondagaon District of Chhattisgarh on June 1 as Aasu Korcha (20), resident of South Bastar and Reena Naretti (27), wife of Ramesh Hupendi, reports Nai Dunia on June 2. Both these slain CPI-Maoist cadres were carrying a reward of INR 5, 00,000 each on their heads. Both the slain CPI-Maoist cadres were involved in the arson in Kusanmari area under Dhanora Police Station in March and several other Naxal \[Left Wing Extremism (LWE)\] incidents in the area. The deceased women, Reena Naretti, who is from Tamoda village in Amabeda of Kanker District, have been involved in several CPI-Maoist incidents like spreading panic and working with Naxal outfits. More than half a dozen offences have been registered under sections of murder, attempt to murder, arson, including explosives, arms act, UAPA and IPC. **Read less...** | | June - 2 June - 3 | Cadres of the Tritiya Prastuti Committee (TPC), a splinter group of the Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist), demanded ‘levy’ (extortion money) from Nityanand Das, Block Development Officer (BDO) of Manatu, after which he registered an FIR a **Read more...** Cadres of the Tritiya Prastuti Committee (TPC), a splinter group of the Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist), demanded ‘levy’ (extortion money) from Nityanand Das, Block Development Officer (BDO) of Manatu, after which he registered an FIR at Manatu Police Station in Palamu District of Jharkhand on June 3, reports UNI. The BDO in his complaint said that on Wednesday (June 2) morning around 10 AM he had first received the call but since the voice was not clear a second call came to him. From the other side, the man identified himself as Nagina Ji of the TPC and demanded money for running the organisation over which the BDO had said that he will speak with the seniors in this regard and had cut the phone. In his complaint, the officer also said that between 12.12 PM to 12.17 PM on Thursday (June 3) he had received five calls on his number for ‘levy’ but the amount was not specified. **Read less...** | | June - 2 | Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) Communication ‘Chief’ in Bijapur District of Chhattisgarh and senior leader of Dandakaranya Special Zonal Committee (DKSZC), identified as Sobroi alias Gaddam Madhukar alias Mohan, carrying a reward of IN **Read more...** Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) Communication ‘Chief’ in Bijapur District of Chhattisgarh and senior leader of Dandakaranya Special Zonal Committee (DKSZC), identified as Sobroi alias Gaddam Madhukar alias Mohan, carrying a reward of INR 800,000 over his head and one CPI-Maoist courier were arrested by Telangana Police on Peddammagadda Cross Road close to Mulugu Road in Warangal District of Telangana on June 2, reports Free Press Journal. Gaddam Madhukar and a courier were arrested during a vehicle-check by Police. Madhukar was suffering from Covid-19, had come to Warangal for the treatment with the help of the courier, a minor. Several cases against him were pending in the Police Stations of Bastar Division. Madhukar who hails from Kumaram Bheem Asifabad District in Telangana had joined the Sirpur Dalam (armed squad) of the then People’s War Group (PWG)) in 1999. The Naxal \[Left Wing Extremism (LWE)\] outfit later shifted him to DKSZC and since then, he was involved in several offences including killing of Police personnel and snatching away their weapons. The CPI-Maoist courier went to Venkatapuram forest area in a car and was bringing Madhukar to Hanamkonda for admission in a hospital. When Police searched the vehicle at the check post, Madhukar was found hiding in the car’s boot. Police arrested both of them and seized INR 88,000 cash. Madhukar was later admitted to a hospital for treatment, said Warangal’s Commissioner of Police, Tarun Joshi. Madhukar informed to Police that a large number of senior Maoist cadres are suffering with COVID-19. But the CPI-Maoist is not allowing them to go outside for better treatment. The cadres in exceptional cases are allowed to go outside for getting better treatment, only after their health condition turns worse. Maoist leaders said found to be infected with Covid- 19 include Telangana State Committee Secretary Yapa Narayana alias Haribhushan alias Lakma, Telangana State Committee members Bade Chokka Rao alias Damodar, and Kankanala Raji Reddy alias Dharmanna alias Venkatesh, DKSZC members Katta Ramchandra Reddy alias Vikalp and Kunkati Venkataiah alias Vikas, DKSZC spokesperson Mula Devender Reddy alias Masa Dada, South Bastar Divisional Committee (DVC) Secretary, Muchaki Ungal alias Raghu alias Sudhakar, and other CPI-Maoist cadres Kodi Manjula, Pusam Padma and Kakarla Sunitha, added Tarun Joshi, reports The Hindu on June 2 **Read less...** | | June - 3 | Chhattisgarh Government has withdrawn 594 criminal cases, including more than 100 CPI-Maoist related cases against tribals in Chhattisgarh, reports The Times of India on June 4. A court acquitted all the accused after reviewing the recommendation of **Read more...** Chhattisgarh Government has withdrawn 594 criminal cases, including more than 100 CPI-Maoist related cases against tribals in Chhattisgarh, reports The Times of India on June 4. A court acquitted all the accused after reviewing the recommendation of a high-level committee. The high-level seven-member committee under the chairmanship of Justice A K Patnaik was constituted in December 2018 by Chhattisgarh State Government headed by Chief Minister (CM) Bhupesh Bagheal to review the criminal cases lodged against innocent tribals in the Maoist insurgency affected Districts. The committee had recommended the withdrawal of 627 cases and based on the recommendation, 594 cases have been withdrawn from the court, benefiting 726 persons. Similarly, 365 Maoist-related cases were identified by the Police department for speedy trial in the courts, in which 218 undertrials were acquitted in 124 cases. Of these, 36 people were acquitted in 24 cases in Dantewada District, 47 people in 44 cases in Bijapur District, nine people in seven cases in Narayanpur District and nine in three cases in Kondagaon District, six people were acquitted in one case in Kanker District, 109 people in 44 cases in Sukma District and two accused in one case in Rajnandgaon District. **Read less...** | | June - 3 | Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) in a pamphlet have again strongly opposed the excavation work of the Surajgarh Iron Ore project and warned the workers involved in excavation work to be killed in Gadchiroli District of Maharashtra, report **Read more...** Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) in a pamphlet have again strongly opposed the excavation work of the Surajgarh Iron Ore project and warned the workers involved in excavation work to be killed in Gadchiroli District of Maharashtra, reports Sakal on June 4. The letter of Naxals \[Left Wing Extremism (LWE)\] was found at Surajangarh Iron Mineral Hill. In the past, CPI-Maoist cadres have set ablaze 83 vehicles in the area opposing this project. **Read less...** | | June - 3 | Police arrested Nath Ganjhu alias Bhagirath, an ‘area commander’ of the Tritiya Prastuti Committee (TPC), a splinter group of the Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist), from Bharkudwa village under Lawalong Police Station area in Chatra Distri **Read more...** Police arrested Nath Ganjhu alias Bhagirath, an ‘area commander’ of the Tritiya Prastuti Committee (TPC), a splinter group of the Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist), from Bharkudwa village under Lawalong Police Station area in Chatra District of Jharkhand on June 3, reports UNI. An US-made rifle, one .315 bore rifle, 30 cartridges of different guns, Naxal \[Left Wing extremism, LWE\] literature and TPC pamphlets have been recovered from the possession of Bhagirath. **Read less...** | | June - 3 | Police recovered two fake AK-47s, CPI-Maoist uniforms, and a bag from a forest near Dugeli village under Bacheli Police Station limits in Dantewada District of Chhattisgarh, reports Ommcom News on June 4. Police team visited the village and had discu **Read more...** Police recovered two fake AK-47s, CPI-Maoist uniforms, and a bag from a forest near Dugeli village under Bacheli Police Station limits in Dantewada District of Chhattisgarh, reports Ommcom News on June 4. Police team visited the village and had discussion with the residents, after receiving information about the fake CPI-Maoist activities in the area. Police team recovered two fake AK-47s, CPI-Maoist uniforms, and a bag hidden inside a hole. The AK-47s had been carved from wood and were being used by fake CPI-Maoist cadres to threaten the villagers. They used to enter the village during the night, kidnap wealthy people and collect ransom from their relatives. Unable to identify the weapons during the night, villagers also gave them money and other things. Police have launched a campaign to arrest them with the help of the villagers, said Dantewada Superintendent of Police (SP) Abhishek Pallav. **Read less...** | | June - 3 | Two teenage CPI-Maoist cadres have surrendered before the Security Forces (SFs) at Bhandaria Police Station of Garhwa District in Jharkhand on June 3, reports Dainik Jagran. Both these teenage CPI-Maoist cadres are 16 and 17 years old. One of them is **Read more...** Two teenage CPI-Maoist cadres have surrendered before the Security Forces (SFs) at Bhandaria Police Station of Garhwa District in Jharkhand on June 3, reports Dainik Jagran. Both these teenage CPI-Maoist cadres are 16 and 17 years old. One of them is from Karamdih Police Station limits of Latehar District and another is from Bhandaria Police Station limits in Garhwa District of Jharkhand. They were active members of Dalam (armed squad) of CPI-Maoist ‘commander’ Vimaji who carries a reward of INR 2.5 million for the past 18 months, said Superintendent of Police (SP) Srikant S Khotre **Read less...** | | June - 4 | Former Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) identified as Chhatradhar Mahato, the face of the CPI-Maoist backed tribal movement of 2008-11 in Lalgarh and presently a Trinamool Congress functionary moved the National Investigation Agency (NIA **Read more...** Former Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) identified as Chhatradhar Mahato, the face of the CPI-Maoist backed tribal movement of 2008-11 in Lalgarh and presently a Trinamool Congress functionary moved the National Investigation Agency (NIA) court on June 4 seeking house arrest, citing the Covid-19 situation and his failing health, reports Times of India on June 6. The former CPI-Maoist leader arrested in the 2009 Rajdhani Express hijack case has moved the NIA (NIA) court through a lawyer. On October 27, 2009, the Rajdhani Express was stopped at Banstala station in Jhargram District of West Bengal, adds Sangbad Pratidin **Read less...** | | June - 4 | Security Forces (SFs) recovered Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) weapons including two guns, a pistol, gelatin, electronic detonator, which were tied to plastic under the ground in Jamti forest under Bishanpur Police Station area of Guml **Read more...** Security Forces (SFs) recovered Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) weapons including two guns, a pistol, gelatin, electronic detonator, which were tied to plastic under the ground in Jamti forest under Bishanpur Police Station area of Gumla District of Jharkhand during a search operation, reports News 18 on June 5. A joint SFs team comprising of Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF) 158 Battalion and District Police had information that CPI-Maoist ‘zonal commander’ Ravindra Ganju and his associates were active in the forest before the search operation. CPI-Maoist cadres have fled the location before the team of SFs had arrived to the location. **Read less...** | | June - 4 | Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) cadre identified as Madakam Nandal alias Nandu (20), a resident of Kourugutt village of Pameda Mandal (administrative sub-division) in Bijapur District of Chhattisgarh surrendered before the Police in Mulu **Read more...** Communist Party of India-Maoist (CPI-Maoist) cadre identified as Madakam Nandal alias Nandu (20), a resident of Kourugutt village of Pameda Mandal (administrative sub-division) in Bijapur District of Chhattisgarh surrendered before the Police in Mulugu District of Telangana on June 4, reports Telangana Today. Nandu was working as a guard to the CPI-Maoist ‘commander’ of Special Guerilla Squad (SGS), Lachanna and he was suffering from ill-health and there was no chance of him getting proper treatment. He joined as a member of Cherla Arunakka Dalam (armed squad) in 2018 with the help of Somudu, an underground cadre, and worked there for one year as a Dalam member. pathway for citizenship for illegal migrants who are [Hindu](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindus), [Sikh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sikhs), [Jain](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jain), [Parsi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsis), [Buddhist](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhist), and [Christian](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christians) from Afghanistan, Bangladesh and Pakistan, and who entered India before 2014, following the [religious persecutions](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_persecution).[\[80\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_explained-80) The bill reduced the time taken for naturalization for this category from twelve years to six years. The bill does not mention [Muslims](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muslims) and other communities who fled from the same or other neighbouring countries. Refugees from [Sri Lankan Tamils in India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sri_Lankan_Tamils_in_India), [Rohingyas](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rohingya) from [Myanmar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myanmar), and [Tibetan refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tibetan_refugees_in_India) are also not mentioned in the bill.[\[81\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IEConception-81)[\[82\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-82) The proposed [National Register of Citizens](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens) (NRC) will be an official record of all legal citizens of India. Individuals would need to provide a prescribed set of documents before a specified cutoff date to be included in it.[\[83\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-83) The amendment has been widely criticised as [discriminating on the basis of religion](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_discrimination), particularity for excluding Muslims.[\[84\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NPRExcludes-84) Protestors against the amendment demand that it be scrapped and that the nationwide NRC not be implemented.[\[85\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-wsjdelhi-85)[\[86\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Sigal_Samuel-86)[\[87\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-87) The bill has raised concerns among the Indian Muslim community.[\[88\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-88)[\[89\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-89)[\[90\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-90)[\[91\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-91) They are also concerned that all citizens will be affected by the bureaucratic exercise of the NRC where they will have to prove their citizenship for inclusion in the registry.[\[92\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-92)[\[93\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-93) The protesters have raised voices against authoritarianism and the police crackdown in universities to suppress protests.[\[3\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AtlanticLate-3)[\[94\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CaravanAuthoritarianism-94) Protesters in [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam) and other [northeastern states](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northeast_India) do not want [Indian citizenship](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_citizenship) to be granted to any refugee or immigrant, regardless of their religion, as they fear it would alter the region's demographic balance, resulting in a loss of their political rights, culture, and land.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95)[\[96\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-iexpressassam-96)[\[97\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-reuters1211-97) They are also concerned that it will motivate further [migration](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_migration) from [Bangladesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangladesh) that could violate the [Assam Accord](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Accord) which was a prior agreement reached with the central government on migrants and refugees.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95)[\[96\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-iexpressassam-96)[\[97\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-reuters1211-97) The protests started in Assam on 4 December 2019, after the bill was introduced in parliament. Later on, protests erupted in [Northeast India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northeast_India), and subsequently spread to the major cities of India. On 15 December, major protests took place near [Jamia Millia Islamia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia) in New Delhi and [Aligarh Muslim University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aligarh_Muslim_University). As the protests broke out, mobs burnt and destroyed public as well as private properties and several railway stations were vandalised.[\[98\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-98)[\[99\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-99)[\[100\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-100) Police [forcibly entered](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Jamia_Milia_Islamia_attack) the campus of Jamia, used batons and [tear gas](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tear_gas) on the students, and more than 200 students were injured while around 100 were detained overnight in the police station. The police action was widely criticised and resulted students across the country protesting in solidarity.[\[101\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-101)[\[102\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-102) The protests resulted in thousands of arrests and 27 deaths as of 27 December 2019.[\[103\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_arrests-103)[\[67\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-aljazeera_27_Dead-67) Two 17-year-old minors were among those reported to have been killed due to police firing during a live ammunition on protesters in Assam.[\[104\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-minors-104) On 19 December, the police issued a complete ban on protests in several parts of India. It amends the [Citizenship Act of 1955](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_nationality_law) to grant a swifter path to Indian citizenship under the assumption of [religious persecution](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_persecution) to any individual belonging to the specific minorities of [Hindus](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindus), [Sikhs](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sikhs), [Buddhists](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhist), [Jains](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jain), [Parsis](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsis) and Christians from [Afghanistan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Afghanistan), [Bangladesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangladesh) and [Pakistan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pakistan), who entered India on or before 31 December 2014.[\[108\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-108) The Act also seeks to relax the requirement of residence in India for citizenship by [naturalisation](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naturalisation) from 11 years to 5 years for migrants covered under the Act.[\[109\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-109) However, the Act does not mention Muslims and does not offer the same eligibility benefits to Muslim immigrants or immigrants belonging to other religions from those countries.[\[110\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Samuel-110) The Act also does not mention any benefits for various other refugees which form the bulk of the refugees living in India, such as [Sri Lankan Tamil refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sri_Lankan_Tamils_in_India) who faced persecution during the [Sri Lankan Civil War](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sri_Lankan_Civil_War),[\[111\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-111) [Rohingya refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rohingya_Refugee_Crisis) who were victims of the [Rohingya genocide](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rohingya_genocide), [Nepali refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhutanese_refugees) who faced [ethnic cleansing in Bhutan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnic_cleansing_in_Bhutan), and [Tibetan Buddhist refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tibetan_refugees_in_India) who faced persecution in China.[\[112\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-WPCitizenship22-112) According to the [Intelligence Bureau](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligence_Bureau_(India)), the immediate beneficiaries of the new law will be 25,447 Hindus, 5,807 Sikhs, 55 Christians, 2 Buddhists and 2 Parsis.[\[113\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-angry22-113) ### Response [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=3) The passage of the Act sparked massive protests in India.[\[110\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Samuel-110) Protesters in [Assam](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam) and other [northeastern states](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northeast_India) oppose the grant of [Indian citizenship](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_citizenship) to any refugee or immigrant, regardless of their religion, because they fear it would alter the region's demographic balance. They have campaigned since the 1970s against all refugees, and they fear that the new law will cause a loss of their political rights, culture and land.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95)[\[96\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-iexpressassam-96)[\[97\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-reuters1211-97) They are also concerned that it will trigger more migration from [Bangladesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangladesh) as well as violate the [Assam Accord](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Accord), which was a prior agreement reached with the central government on migrants and refugees.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95)[\[96\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-iexpressassam-96)[\[97\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-reuters1211-97) After the act was passed, protests in the northeastern region turned violent. Authorities had arrested over 3000 protesters as of 17 December 2019,[\[73\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_17Dec-73) and some news outlets have described these protests as [riots](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riots).[\[114\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-114) Protesters say that the Act violates Clause 5 and Clause 6 of the 1985 [Assam Accord](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Accord).[\[115\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-115) Critics have stated that the amendment Act is unconstitutional.[\[116\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-116)[\[117\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-guardian-117)[\[118\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-118) The major opposition political parties state that it violates Constitution's Article 14, one that guarantees equality to all. They allege that the new law seeks to make Muslims second-class citizens of India, while preferentially treating non-Muslims in India.[\[119\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-119) Critics of the Act have also stated that due to the [National Register of Citizens (NRC)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens_of_India), Muslims could be made [stateless](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statelessness), while the Citizenship Amendment Act would be able to shield people with Hindu, Sikh, Buddhist, Jain, Parsi or Christian identity as a means of providing them with Indian citizenship even if they fail to prove that they were citizens of India under the stringent requirements of the NRC. Some critics allege that it is a deliberate attempt at [disenfranchising](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disfranchisement) and segregating Muslims in line with the [ethnonationalist](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnonationalist) [Hindutva](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindutva) ideology of the ruling [Bharatiya Janata Party](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party) (BJP).[\[120\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-120)[\[81\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IEConception-81)[\[121\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-AsianAgeOrwellian-121) [Tavleen Singh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tavleen_Singh) described the Act as India's first [Nuremberg Law](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuremberg_Laws).[\[122\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-122) The home minister [Amit Shah](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amit_Shah) had previously set a deadline for the implementation of a countrywide NRC by stating that the register would be rolled out before the [2024 Lok Sabha elections](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Indian_general_election).[\[123\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-livemint_NRC-123) The Act was criticised by various NGOs, students bodies, and liberal, progressive, and socialist organisations across the country, with the [Indian National Congress](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_National_Congress) and other major political parties announcing their staunch opposition. Protests led by these groups are concerned that the new law discriminates against Muslims, and believe that Indian citizenship should also be granted to Muslim refugees and immigrants. The states of [Rajasthan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rajasthan), West Bengal, [Kerala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala), Maharashtra, [Madhya Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madhya_Pradesh), Jharkhand[\[124\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-124) and [Chhattisgarh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chhattisgarh) – all ruled by political parties that oppose the BJP – have announced that they will not implement either the [National Register of Citizens](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens) (NRC) or the Citizenship Amendment Act. The states of [Bihar](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bihar), Andhra Pradesh and [Odisha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Odisha) have however refused to only implement the NRC, while the state of [Punjab](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punjab,_India) and the union territories of Delhi and [Puducherry](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puducherry_(union_territory)) have refused to implement the Act while only expressing disapproval of the NRC.[\[125\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-125)[\[126\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-126)[\[127\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-127) The states of [West Bengal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Bengal) and [Kerala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala) have also put a hold on all activities relating to the preparation and update of the [National Population Register](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Population_Register) which is necessary for the Census as well as the implementation of the [National Register of Citizens](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Citizens).[\[128\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-128) Although some of the states have opposed the Act, the [Union Home Ministry](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_Home_Affairs_(India)) clarified that states lack the legal power to stop the implementation of CAA. The Ministry stated that "The new legislation has been enacted under the Union List of the 7th Schedule of the Constitution. The states have no power to reject it."[\[129\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Outlook_MP_19_Dec-129) The [Indian Union Muslim League](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Union_Muslim_League) and various other bodies have also petitioned the [Supreme Court of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_India) to strike down the Act as illegal and unconstitutional.[\[130\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-bbc-130) ## Chronology [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=4) ### December 2019 [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=5) - **4 December** - The Citizenship (Amendment) Bill, 2019 was cleared by the [Union Cabinet](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_Council_of_Ministers) for introduction in the parliament.[\[131\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-131) - After the bill was cleared, violent protests erupted in Assam, especially in [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati), and other areas in the state.[\[132\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ET_CAA_12-132) - In [Dispur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dispur), several thousands of protesters broke down police barricades to protest in front of the [Assam Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Legislative_Assembly) building.[\[133\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-133)[\[134\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-New_York_Times-134) - Demonstrations were held in [Agartala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agartala).[\[135\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-135) Six people died and fifty people were injured in the protests against the Act.[\[136\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-136)[\[137\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_16_Dec-137) - **9 December** - The bill was introduced in the [Lok Sabha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lok_Sabha) by the Minister of Home Affairs, [Amit Shah](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amit_Shah).[\[138\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-138) - **10 December** - The bill was passed with 311 members voting in favour and 80 against.[\[139\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-139)[\[140\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-140) - **11 December** - The bill was subsequently passed by the [Rajya Sabha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rajya_Sabha) with 125 votes in favour and 105 votes against it. Those parties that had voted in favour include BJP allies such as the [Janata Dal (United)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janata_Dal_(United)) and the [AIADMK](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_India_Anna_Dravida_Munnetra_Kazhagam) and non-aligned parties such as the [Biju Janata Dal](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biju_Janata_Dal).[\[141\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Hindu_RS_Passed-141) - **12 December** - After receiving assent from the [President of India](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_India), the bill assumed the status of an act.[\[142\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-assent-142) The act would come into force on 10 January, chosen by the Government of India, and would be notified as such.[\[143\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-gazette-143)[\[144\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CAA_in_force_10_Jan-144) - Dipanjal Das and Sam Stafford were killed in police firing during a protest in Guwahati.[\[145\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto3-145) - [Akhil Gogoi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akhil_Gogoi) was taken in preventive custody.[\[146\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITAkhil19-146) A poster at Shaheen Bagh protests New Delhi - [Puducherry](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pondicherry).[\[402\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-402)[\[403\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-403)[\[404\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Washington_Post_16-404) Between 16 and 18 December, a statement of solidarity "condemning the recent police action and brutalization of students at Jamia Millia University and Aligarh Muslim University" had acquired 10,293 signatories from over 1,100 universities, colleges and academic institutions across the world. Scholars from major academic institutions in India, including [JNU](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/JNU_Delhi), [Delhi University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_University), all the [Indian Institutes of Technology](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institutes_of_Technology), the [Indian Statistical Institute](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Statistical_Institute), the [Tata Institute of Fundamental Research](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tata_Institute_of_Fundamental_Research), among many others had signed the solidarity statement.[\[94\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CaravanAuthoritarianism-94) On 16 December, professors and students of [IIM-Ahmedabad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Management_Ahmedabad) were detained by police citing demonstrating protest against the Act is illegal.[\[405\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-405) On 19 December police banned protests in several parts of India with the imposition of [Section 144](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unlawful_assembly#India) which prohibits the gathering of more than 4 individuals in a public space as being unlawful, namely, parts of the capital [New Delhi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi), Uttar Pradesh, and [Karnataka](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karnataka), including Bangalore. As Section 144 was imposed, the students of [IIM-Bangalore](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Management_Bangalore) demonstrate their protest peacefully by laying shoes and placards in front of the institute gate, which they called the Shoe [Satyagraha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satyagraha).[\[406\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-406) Following IIM-Ahmedabad and Bangalore, [IIM-Calcutta](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Management_Calcutta) raised their voice peacefully in solidarity against the Act and the brutal misconduct by police against the students who were protesting all over the country.[\[407\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-407) Several institutes in [Kozhikode](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kozhikode) including [IIM-Kozhikode](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Institute_of_Management_Kozhikode), [NIT-Calicut](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Institute_of_Technology_Calicut), [Government Medical College, Kozhikode](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_Medical_College,_Kozhikode) and [Farook College](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farook_College) expressed their protest from 19 to 20 December.[\[408\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-408) Police in [Chennai](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chennai) denied permission for marches, rallies or any other demonstration.[\[409\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-409)[\[410\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-410) Internet services were also shutdown in some parts of Delhi. As a result of defying the ban, thousands of protesters were detained, primarily in Delhi, including several opposition leaders and activists such as [Ramachandra Guha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramachandra_Guha), [Sitaram Yechury](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sitaram_Yechury), [Yogendra Yadav](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yogendra_Yadav), [Umar Khalid](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Umar_Khalid), [Sandeep Dikshit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sandeep_Dikshit), and [D Raja](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/D_Raja).[\[411\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-411)[\[412\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-412)[\[413\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-413) Despite the fear of being detained, tens of thousands of people protested in Hyderabad, Patna, Chandigarh, Mumbai and other cities. Civil society groups, political parties, students, activists and ordinary citizens used social medial platforms to ask people to turn up and protest peacefully.[\[172\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_19_Dec-172) The protests involving 20,000 protesters concluded peacefully at the [August Kranti Maidan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/August_Kranti_Maidan) at Mumbai.[\[179\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Mumbai_Mirror_19-179) More than 300 eminent personalities in India signed and issued an open statement against the CAA. The signatories including actor [Naseeruddin Shah](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naseeruddin_Shah), Ratna Patak Shah, Jaaved Jafferi, Nandita Das, Lillete Dubey film-maker [Mira Nair](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mira_Nair), writers Anita Desai, Kiran Desai, actors, sociologist Ashis Nandy, activists Sohail Hashmi and Shabnam Hashmi among others.[\[300\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-26_Jan_300_sign-300) ### Assam [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=13) Mass Gathering of Anti Citizenship Act protests at Chandmari, [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati), AssamA [Rangoli](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rangoli) created as a part of protests against anti Citizenship Act 2019 at Chandmari, [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati), Assam Students of [Cotton University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cotton_University) began protesting against the CAA a few days before the controversial bill was produced on the floor of the [Lok Sabha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lok_Sabha). On 29 November, the students staged a silent protest outside the university campus.[\[414\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-414)[\[415\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-415) After the bill was cleared on 4 December 2019, violent protests erupted in Assam, especially in [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati), and other areas in the state.[\[132\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ET_CAA_12-132) _[Reuters](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reuters)_ reported that the protests in the state were violent, adding that at least two people were killed till 16 December. Buildings and railway stations were set on fire. The CAA made 2014 as the cut-off date to determine illegal foreigners but according to people opposing the act, Assam bore the brunt of immigrants from 1951 to 1971, while other states did not.[\[416\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-416)[\[417\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-417)[\[418\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-418) The protesters were angry that the new law would allow thousands of [Bengali](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bengali_language) speaking non-Muslim [immigrants from Bangladesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illegal_immigration_to_India#Bangladeshi_immigrants) to become legal citizens of India,[\[155\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Reuters16Dec-155)[\[130\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-bbc-130) thereby influencing the political and cultural environment of Assam.[\[419\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-419) Thousands of members and workers of the [All Assam Students Union (AASU)](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_Assam_Students%27_Union) and 30 other indigenous organisations, artists, cultural activists of the state gathered at Latasil ground in Dispur to stage a [satyagraha](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satyagraha) against the Act on 16, 17 and 18 December.[\[420\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-420)[\[162\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITAASU-162) [Assam Police](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Police) subsequently detained the general secretary and the [adviser](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adviser) to the AASU and over 2,000 protesters in Guwahati during a protest rally on 18 December.[\[421\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-421)[\[422\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-422) On 12 December, security personnel, including [CRPF](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Reserve_Police_Force) jawans with batons and shields barged into the office of a private TV channel of Assam, _[Prag News](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prag_News)_ in Guwahati and attacked its staffers with batons during protests.[\[423\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-423) On 20 December, [Assamese language](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assamese_language) newspapers reported violent incidents occurring during the protests across the state. Use of excessive force by the police was also reported.[\[424\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-424) In [Dibrugarh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dibrugarh), the All Assam Students Union members vandalised the district office of the [Asom Gana Parishad](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asom_Gana_Parishad), which had voted in favour of the act as part of the ruling Coalition.[\[425\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HBL-425)[\[426\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-426) Peasant leader [Akhil Gogoi](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akhil_Gogoi) was arrested in [Jorhat](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jorhat) on 12 December as a preventive measure by authorities to prevent him from organising any protests. A special court of [National Investigation Agency](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Investigation_Agency) (NIA) in Guwahati on Tuesday charged him under [sedition](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedition) for " [maoist](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maoism) links" and sent him to 10-day NIA custody. The [Assam Human rights Commission](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Human_rights_Commission) decided to take suo moto cognizance of reports of alleged torture upon Akhil Gogoi.[\[427\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-427)[\[428\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-428) According to the [Assam Government](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Government), people have been arrested by the Assam Police for their alleged involvement in the violent incidents during the anti-CAA protests across the state, as of 17 December.[\[146\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ITAkhil19-146)[\[429\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-429) In [Dispur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dispur), several thousands of protesters broke down police barricades to protest in front of the [Assam Legislative Assembly](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assam_Legislative_Assembly) building.[\[430\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-430)[\[134\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-New_York_Times-134) Demonstrations were also held in [Agartala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agartala).[\[431\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-431) On 15 December 2019, a concert was staged by artistes of Assam as a protest against the CAA. The concert was themed as 'No CAA, Concert for peace and harmony'. Along with music, paintings were also demonstrated in the event.[\[432\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-432)[\[433\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-433) Access to the internet was restricted in Assam by the administrative authorities.[\[103\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-IT_arrests-103) A curfew was also declared in Assam and [Tripura](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tripura) due to the protests,[\[130\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-bbc-130) leading to army deployment as protesters defied the curfews. Railway services were suspended and some airlines started to waive rescheduling or cancellation fees in those areas.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95) Officials reported that at least four people died after clashes with police in [Guwahati](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guwahati).[\[434\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-434)[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95) Two men, Dipanjal Das and Sam Stafford, died due to police firing on 12 December.[\[145\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto3-145)[\[435\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-435) On 15 December, [Gauhati Medical College and Hospital](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauhati_Medical_College_and_Hospital) official stated that Ishwar Nayak died on the night of 14 December and Abdul Alim died on 15 December morning. Both of them had been admitted to the hospital after suffering gunshot wounds.[\[149\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-quint_CAA-149) As of 15 December, it was reported that at least 6 people had died due to police firing during the protests.[\[436\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-436) After ten days of restriction, mobile internet services in the state were restored from 20 December, although the [Gauhati High Court](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauhati_High_Court) had ordered the government of Assam to restore the service by 5 pm on 19 December.[\[437\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-437) By 22 December, the number of arrested people rose to 393, with 28 cases being registered for making offensive and provocative posts on social media.[\[438\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-auto4-438) On 21 December, an all-woman protest was organised across the state.[\[184\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-ReutersHundreds-184) Senior citizens across the state protested on 23 December.[\[439\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-439) Chowkidinghee playground in [Dibrugarh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dibrugarh_district) saw one of the largest mass gatherings of CAA protests in Assam organised by All Assam Students' Union on 24 December.[\[440\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-440) On 8 January, PM Modi cancelled his visit to Assam while the protests continued in the state. AASU had planned huge protests during Modi's visit.[\[240\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-TNIE_Modi_8_Jan-240)[\[241\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Outlook_8_Jan-241) Thousands of people joined the anti-CAA protests at Dibrugarh, Guwahati and other parts of Assam.[\[242\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Telegraph_8_January-242) The protesters dressed up in traditional dress of the region and sang devotional songs during the protest. The protesters also demanded the release of Akhil Gogoi and called the [Modi government](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modi_government) a dictatorship.[\[243\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-nenow_8_January_2020-243) On 9 January, musical protests were planned at Gauhati Club in Assam by AASU, along with 30 other organisations and artist communities.[\[242\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Telegraph_8_January-242) On 22 January, thousands of students from 9 universities in North East India boycotted classes and joined a protest march in the states of Assam, [Nagaland](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nagaland), Meghalaya and [Arunachal Pradesh](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arunachal_Pradesh).[\[284\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-HT_22_Jan_Assam-284) ### Tripura [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=14) Several protests marches with thousands of protesters were held in Tripura. On 12 December _BBC_ reported that the army had been deployed in the state and around 1800 people were arrested.[\[95\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-BBC_2_Dead-95) Around 200 protesters were detained by police during a protest in the capital city of [Agartala](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agartala).[\[441\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-441) On 11 December, [Pradyot Manikya Debbarma](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pradyot_Manikya_Debbarma), the royal scion, led the largest protest in Tripura so far consisting of thousands of people.[\[252\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_12_Jan-252) Debbarma stated that beneficiaries of CAA would not be allowed to settle in Tripura. He added that the state has already accommodated many migrants from [East Pakistan](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Pakistan) and further immigration due to CAA would endanger the threatened indigenous residents of the state.[\[252\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_12_Jan-252) The Act also ignited old conflicts between the Bengalis and the [Reang refugees](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reang#The_Displaced_Reangs). Fresh clashes were reported in the northern district of [Kanchanpur](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanchanpur_District) between the two communities. The Reang refugees were protesting against the CAA while the Hindu Bengalis were supporting it. Protesters reportedly threw stones and vandalised shops and a marketplace.[\[442\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-442) ### Crackdown on Universities [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=15) #### Jamia Millia Islamia [edit](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests&action=edit&section=16) Main article: [2019 Jamia Milia Islamia attack](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Jamia_Milia_Islamia_attack) On 13 December 2019, the students of [Jamia Millia Islamia University](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamia_Millia_Islamia_University) undertook a march to the Parliament protesting against the CAA. They were prevented from going ahead by the police who used batons and tear gas to disperse the protesters leading to clashes with them. Fifty students were detained by the police after the clash. According to the students, police attacked the peaceful protesters with stones and sticks, and several students were injured. The students then retaliated, and clashes ensued. Police denied the allegations, also claiming that the protesters attacked the policemen with stones after they were stopped from marching onwards. Police then used tear gas to disperse them.[\[443\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-The_Hindu_13_Jamia-443) On the morning of 15 December 2019, more than two thousand students of Jamia joined the protests against CAA in Delhi.[\[444\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-CNN_spread-444) Jamia Millia Student Body and Jamia Millia Islamia Teacher's Association (JTA) condemned the violence that happened on the same day in Delhi and stated that no student or teacher was involved in the violence.[\[149\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-quint_CAA-149) At 6:46 pm on 15 December 2019, hundreds of police officers forcefully entered the campus of Jamia, without the permission of college authority.[\[149\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-quint_CAA-149) The police used batons and tear gas on the protesting students.[\[404\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-Washington_Post_16-404) Nearly a hundred students were detained by the Delhi police and released at 3:30 am next morning.[\[445\]](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citizenship_Amendment_Act_protests#cite_note-NDTV_Police_station-445) The visuals of students being dragged and [assaulted](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assaulted) by the police was telecast by news channels.
